brief_rationale: Well-known art term frequently encountered in general education and popular culture.
Major modern art movement widely recognized through Dali and other famous artists.
Arguably the most famous painting in the world, universally recognizable.
Widely recognized decorative style associated with iconic architecture and design.
One of the most famous archaeological discoveries, known to any educated person.
Iconic work by Michelangelo that most educated people can identify.
Widely recognized design movement associated with prominent buildings and everyday objects.
Fundamental art technique known from Roman and Byzantine contexts, widely recognized.
Major avant-garde movement referenced frequently in art history surveys.
The world's most visited art museum, a cultural landmark known globally.
One of the most famous ancient sculptures, widely recognizable by the general public.
Major Western art and architectural movement broadly covered in general education.
One of the most reproduced and recognized artworks worldwide.
Specific Renaissance painting technique associated with Leonardo, less widely known than chiaroscuro.
Important sculptural pose requiring knowledge of Classical art vocabulary.
Significant African art objects increasingly prominent in repatriation debates, but not universally known.
Important South Asian miniature tradition that requires specific art-historical knowledge.
Specific still-life genre requiring knowledge of Dutch Golden Age painting conventions.
Specific painting practice linked to Impressionism that requires art vocabulary knowledge.
Specific painting medium requiring knowledge of historical art materials and techniques.
Important sculptural technique used across many cultures, requires technical art knowledge.
Specific painting technique requiring familiarity with studio vocabulary.
Key decorative motif in Islamic art requiring knowledge beyond Western-centric art history.
Medieval art period requiring ability to distinguish it from Gothic and earlier styles.
Early photographic movement that requires knowledge of photography as fine art.
Contemporary art form requiring understanding of how art expanded beyond traditional media.
Requires understanding how Japanese art influenced Western modernism and cross-cultural exchange.
Requires working knowledge of art authentication, market practices, and legal issues.
Requires understanding of institutional art history and the emergence of modernism.
Requires understanding Duchamp's conceptual challenge to traditional definitions of art.
Requires knowledge of South Asian Buddhist art and its place in global art history.
Requires understanding how artistic styles migrated across civilizations through trade networks.
Requires knowledge of Pre-Columbian Mesoamerican sculpture and its cultural context.
Requires understanding the precursors to modern museums and early collecting practices.
Requires working knowledge of authentication methods, famous cases, and market implications.
Requires understanding the intersection of politics, ideology, and modern art history.
Requires knowledge of Japanese aesthetics and the philosophical dimensions of craft repair.
Requires understanding the institutional gatekeeping that shaped European art from the 17th to 19th centuries.
Renaissance theoretical debate over the superiority of painting versus sculpture, requiring deep art-theory knowledge.
Foundational art historian whose iconographic method requires scholarly familiarity with art historiography.
Classical art-theoretical concept comparing poetry and painting, requiring knowledge of aesthetic philosophy.
Advanced contemporary art practice requiring understanding of museum politics and critical theory.
Requires nuanced understanding of postmodern strategies, copyright debates, and art theory.
Edward Said's theoretical framework requiring deep engagement with postcolonial critique of art representation.
Scholarly debate about original color on ancient sculpture that challenges popular assumptions about classical art.
Rhetorical and literary concept describing art in words, requiring knowledge of classical and Renaissance art theory.
Complex legal and ethical debates about museum collections requiring deep knowledge of art law and postcolonial discourse.

concept: The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction
wikipedia_article: The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction
brief_rationale: Walter Benjamin's seminal essay on aura and reproduction, a cornerstone of critical art theory.
Art-historical methodology of attribution through visual analysis, requiring understanding of historiographic debates.
Japanese aesthetic philosophy of imperfection and transience requiring deep cross-cultural aesthetic knowledge.
